VI.	General Accidental Release Prevention Program

A prevention program is in place to minimize the risk of hazardous chemical releases in accordance with the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (29 CFR 1910.119) and the EPA Risk Management Program.   

This prevention program covers those processes that utilize ethylene oxide above the threshold quantity for both PSM and RMP rules. 
 

VII.	Five-Year Accident History

The Baxter facility has not experienced an accidental ethylene oxide release, which resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

VIII.	Emergency Response Program

Baxter has developed an Emergency Action Plan (EAP) to ensure that in the event of an emergency the facility personnel are aware of the appropriate actions to take and authorities to contact in order to mitigate the effects of a release. 

Baxter has communicated and trained facility employees on proper evacuation procedures and has interacted (i.e. onsite inspections) with the Mountain Home Fire Department. 

Baxter has coordinated their EAP with the Mountain Home Fire Department.  This coordination effort includes providing the agency with a copy of our EAP, and providing a site diagram and hazardous material information, meeting with Mountain Home Fire Department personnel to discuss the facility's operations/processes, and encouraging periodic on-site inspections and coordination with Mountain Home Fire Department personnel.

Currently, Baxter does not have designated personnel as members of a hazardous materials response team. The facility will rely on response by the Mountain Home Fire Department and HAZMAT Team, in the event of a ethylene oxide release.

The facility utilizes a windsock onsite to determine wind direction in the event of an ethylene oxide release and evacuation of t

he building.  The windsock is located on the EO Shed. 

The current Safety Data Sheet (SDS) for ethylene oxide is included in Appendix E. 

IX.	Emergency Communications

The telephone numbers of agencies and plant personnel that may be contacted in case of an emergency are available onsite.
 

X.	Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Chemical safety is a paramount element of Baxter operations. Baxter recently conducted a process hazard analysis (PHA) of their ethylene oxide system and will be dutifully implementing the recommendations from that PHA. Continuous improvement in safety is an important goal for Baxter.  

XI.	Management  System

Baxter has developed a management system to oversee the implementation of the risk management program elements.  This system has assigned qualified person(s) (or position) to assist in the development, implementation, and integration of the risk management program elements.  If any portion of the program is delegated to others, the names or positions of those individuals will be documented and the lines of authority defined through an organization chart or similar document.  Currently, Fernanda Ribeiro, Senior PSM Specialist of Baxter is responsible for implementation of the overall Risk Management Program.

designed to maximize the safety of all employees, contractors, and visitors in the event of an emergency and also guard against environmental consequences.



III.	Facility Identification

The Baxter facility is located at 1900 Highway 201 N in Mountain Home, Arkansas. Baxter is a hospital products and pharmaceutical manufacturer specializing in IV solutions and premixed drugs, IV infusion pumps and administration sets, parenteral nutrition, etc.

The NAICS code for the facility is 325412. The facility uses ethylene oxide for product sterilization, and is regulated under 40 CFR Part 68, the EPA RMP Rule. 

Two (2), 400 pound cylinders of ethylene oxide are connected to each sterilization vessel at all times. In Vessel 7 drum room there is one (1) sterilization vessel in use at one time and a capacity to store six (6) cylinders, for a total of eight (8) ethylene oxide cylinders or 3,200 pounds. In the new drum room, there are a total of six (6) sterilization vessels used at one time and a capacity to store six (6) cylinders, for a total of eighteen (18) ethylene oxide cylinders, or 7200 pounds. In addition, the total capacity of the outdoor storage facility is thirty (30) cylinders, resulting in a potential of 12,000 pounds of ethylene oxide in the outdoor storage facility. Therefore, the total potential quantity of ethylene on-site is approximately 22,400 pounds.

An aerial map identifying the site location is included as Appendix A. 

IV.	Hazard Assessment - Worse Case Scenarios (WCS)
Appendix B consists of the RMP*Submit Printout and contains additional information on the worst-case scenario. Appendix C consists of the offsite consequence analysis data and maps for the worse case release scenario. 

V.	Hazard Assessment - Alternative Release Scenarios (ARS)
